oooh - i actually had to deal with something similar. are you getting a read only problem?
pretty much.  it's an obvious permissions issue.  i can open and edit the file, but the livecd doesn't have write perms.  it's a fresh, clean install of 10.04
due to toshiba's FUBAR'd ACPI system, you have to run noapic to get it to boot, but the install doesn't give me the chance to do so, so i need to use the livecd to make the change in grub lol
you gotta remount the drive. gimme a second and i should be able to find how to do it
thanks mate, googling while asking, but i'm a fan of simultaneous effort for faster solutions lol
so my issue is that I actually bombed my fstab & had no cd-rom. struggled a bit to find the right way to enable read/write. i think this one didn't work for me, but try: mount -o remount,rw /
can't find it in the fstab lol.  looking up how i can specify all it needs in the command (been a while, i'm rusty)
you don't need to mess with the fstab - that was specific to my problem just remount your drive on the command line
where did ubuntu mount the drive to? I'll tailor a command for it
/media/[long alphanumeric string]
alright  gimme 1 second
appreciate it

standby for pastebin

the last line I see (17) is a virtual file system. i still don't see your hd
if you try to modify directly /etc/default/grub you're gonna run into problems because that's a virtual file
last line should be 18.  it reads:
end goal is simply to apend "noapic" to the line that normally just reads "quiet splash" for the default boot
Ah - couldn't get it from refreshing... But yea - are you trying to modify /media/965a5f1e-062e-4c9c-8dd6-a2666cadbbd2/etc/default/grub?
that's the one you want...
yup, and it's saying i don't have perms when i try to overwrite it
maybe i'm overcomplicating it.  gonna try to copy the file, edit the copy, then paste it over (maybe it's just the CLI editor that doesn't want to do it)
ummm - that's pretty weird. you are using sudo to modify it right?
of course lol.  exactly command was: sudoedit /media/[that long string]/etc/default/grub
just making sure :P - sometimes people try silly things. try to sudo touch something in that folder and see if it lets you
nothing happens.  i enter: sudo touch ./grub (cd'd into the right dir, don't worry), and it just gives me another line

did the m-time change? just seeing if you can write at all to that location.  alternatively "sudo touch test" and see if an empty file test gets made. (just delete right afterwards if it does). if it doesnt you can't write to that folder at all
maybe i'm going about it the wrong way.  if i create my own grub on the VFS from the livecd, can i load that into the actual grub bootloader on the HDD?
it created test
got some new info.  i can create files in that folder, but once created, i no longer own them, and cannot write to or remove them

you should definitely be able to modify that file then :\ you can certainly try to replace the file if you think that's easier. id first try to do a "sudo mv grub grub.bak" and see if it lets u move it
that's awfully weird. i mean, you shouldnt own them because you are creating them with sudo (so they are owned by root) but you should still be able to edit them
that worked rofl
you're telling me? lol
i should now be able to copy over MY version of grub; let you know if it works
seems like you should. extremely retarded though :\
nope, can't copy it, but i'm doing it from the GUI, not with sudo, so that might be why. stand by
this is so bizarre...
got it.  had to create the file on the VFS, then sudo mv it into the HDD's etc/default folder; freaking insane >_< lol

update-grub takes no arguments & it uses default filesystem locations

np - if you really need to generate the cfg file using update-grub keep in mind it's just a wrapped for grub-mkconfig.
but isn't the /etc/default/grub just there for reference?  you need to use update-grub to actual load that into the bootloader, don't you?
pretty close. more less the grub.cfg is generated/updated from the /etc/default/grub when you run update-grub
when you run update-grub i believe all it does is "grub-mkconfig --output=/boot/grub/grub.cfg
